text: - Hello, and welcome to Community Chats.

I'm Aley Hammer, and today we're
joined with Chris Thompson,

the co-founder and CEO
from Amber Electric.

Chris, I'm stoked to have
you on the show today

'cause I just read, actually,
as I woke up this morning,

that you guys have won
the Governor of Victoria's
Startup of the Year Award.
That's so cool, congratulations.

Can you start by telling
our audience a little bit

about Amber Electric and
your background as well?
- Yeah, thanks, Aley.
We're really humbled by this.

I mean, I think, you know, at
the end of the day with that,

though, we don't actually
do anything ourselves,
it's all our customers' work
and all our customers' making impact.
So it's a real tribute, I think,

to us having the most
amazing customers of anyone
in the energy business.
Amber really started from an observation

about where we are right now
in our energy transition.

So, increasingly, we are
starting to power Australia

by wind and by sun,
which is amazing, right?
But obviously it's not always windy
and it's not always sunny.

And so, increasingly, the
challenge we're starting to see
in the overall energy grid

is that we actually can't
integrate more renewables
into the grid.

So we're actually running to
the limits of how much wind

and sun we can actually
get, in the energy grid.
And so that's really where Amber comes in.
So we're an entirely new way to buy power.

And so we pass through
realtime, wholesale prices
directly through to customers.

So what happens in our
wholesale energy market
is that when it's windy and sunny,

we get these renewables
flooding into the grid
and pushing down wholesale prices.

And then at other times when
we're relying on coal and gas,
electricity gets much more expensive.

So what we do with Amber
is we actually pass through
the realtime, wholesale prices directly
through to customers,

and we provide them the
transparency to be able to
actually see what's going on in the grid.

And so customers can
actually start to use power

at those cheaper and greener
times, which saves them money

and actually builds demand for
renewables at the same time

I started my career at
Boston Consulting Group.

So I was working for large
corporates here in Australia,

as well as about Southeast
Asia a little bit.

I was briefly actually in
investment banking before that

but I made a much better
consultant than banker.
And then after a few years of consulting,
I actually took a pretty hard right turn.

So I moved to Iran and I
spent two years in Iran
building an e-commerce company there.

So basically trying to
build the Amazon of Iran,

which was a pretty wild, wild
journey, as you can imagine.
I joined that company about six months

after it had launched
and ended up becoming
one of the two managing directors.

And we grew that up about
400 people on the team.

- Wow, I mean, you have such
an interesting background.

I'm absolutely astonished by
everything you've accomplished.
And I would really love to hear one day
a little bit more about your time in Iran.
That's so cool.

But Chris, Amber Electric,
to get back on track,

is doing some amazing work
in the clean energy space.
So I wanted to ask you,

how was Amber Electric
redefining end consumer behavior
for clean energy?

- Yeah, so we're really on
a mission to bring Australia
to 100% renewables, and increasingly,

one of the most powerful
ways that we can do that is

actually help customers
shift when they need energy.

So, back in the old days
when it was mostly a a coal-

and gas-fired grid, it
didn't really matter
when you turned things on.

The coal and gas would
ramp up and ramp down,
just to basically run.

But when you're dealing in
world power by renewables,
it doesn't work that way anymore.

When it's windy and
sunny, you get this cheap,
wholesale energy coming to the grid.

And then at other times
when it's not wind and sunny

you have to rely on
this dirty coal and gas.

So what we're actually
doing is giving people

the transparency about what's
going on in the wholesale
and in the overall grid,

and how much of their power
is coming from renewables
at any given point in time.
And then increasingly,

we're helping customers to
automatically use more power
at those cheaper and greener times.

So the biggest focus that
we have is actually looking

at large devices, such as home
batteries or electric cars

where we actually
automate those devices to

automatically turn on and
charge when it's cheap and green

and automatically turn
off or even potentially

discharge back into the grid
when it's dirty and expensive.
And so you really see this playing out,
I think, most acutely, when you look at
something like an electric car.
So if you're buying an electric car,
which is an amazing thing to be able to do

for the environment, then
if you're coming home
and charging that at 6:00 every night,

you're basically running your
car on coal and gas, right?
Which, you know, why would you do that?
(laughs)
You've gone from oil to coal and gas,

which is maybe a bit of an
improvement, but not a big one.
But if you're actually charging
that EV in the middle of the night

on a nice windy night or
during the middle of the day

when it's coming almost
entirely from solar,

then all of a sudden you're
running that EV on 80%-plus
renewable energy, which obviously, then,

you're really starting to
make a much bigger difference

than if you're just
relying on coal and gas.
We actually last month got--

We've had solar for a while,
we got a battery put in,
a Tesla battery, and it's so fascinating.

I've got the app on my phone
and I'm forever, you know,
looking at when it's peak time.
And it's pretty amazing.

But as you say, the time
when you choose to turn

on the dishwasher and charge
your car is so critical

because, as you say, if you're
doing it when it's not sunny
for us with solar, you're just using
coal and gas again, so 100%.
- Absolutely, and I think we also
starting to see that there's--

And seeing this sort of
distributed energy revolution
start to happen is people, like yourself,

to be able to actually
automate that battery
to actually start to compete in the market
and drive out that coal and gas.

Right?
- Yeah.

- So at the moment,
the coal and gas plants

are often waiting 'til
the sun is about to set,

to then start to ramp up their
prices and charge you more.

But if you've got a battery,
then all of a sudden

you can sort of entirely
reverse that, flip that around

and start actually earning
those prices for yourself
with your battery, rather than--
And at the same time,

powering your neighbors
with their stored solar
which is way better than having to rely on
that coal and gas.
- So cool.
The apps are pretty phenomenal as well.
Like, being able to see that data
and being able to monitor it hour by hour,

well, actually, second by
second, is pretty cool.
Chris, I wanted to ask you,

'cause Amber Electric
recently went through
a re-architecture on AWS.
You know, it's really important to handle

those peaky workloads for
wholesale energy prices.
So can you tell us a little bit more

about the ups and downs
of peaky workloads?
- Yeah, absolutely.

So, the energy market is a
incredibly dynamic market.
I believe it's actually one
of the most dynamic commodity market

in the whole world, the
Australian energy market.

And because so much of what
we do is driven by the market,

we need to have a really
dynamic and flexible
engineering and product setup as well.

So we have a really
event-driven architecture
and we rely heavily on over the serverless
sort of frameworks,

and a serverless sort
of architectural style.
So a lot of Lambdas, is a lot of Cues,
a lot of off-the-shelf product from AWS.

I feel like every six to
nine months we run into
a new bottleneck on part of it,

and so we have to keep
doubling down again and again

on how do we make sure we
get this architecture really,

really lean, 'cause we may
find ourselves, you know,

during a price event in the
market where a giant coal plant
may trip and the whole grid is on edge

and where potentially
you're gonna be seeing
people lose power.

And at those points in time
we wanna be dispatching

all our batteries, making
sure we're controlling
all the devices we can control

to try and help keep the
power on for everyone
as well as minimize people's prices.

And so that means we need to
be taking all those actions

you know, within the space
of 1, 2, 3 seconds, right?

As soon as we get that
notification about what's happening

in the market, we need
to be able to respond

incredibly quickly and and
respond across, you know,

tens of thousands of
customers and devices.
So to be able to do that,
we rely heavily on the AWS infrastructure

and systems to be able
to take in these actions
and then very, very rapidly, at times,
scale up to tens of thousands of different

as your Lambda is running
simultaneously to try
and get those out and get notifications

and responses out to devices
and customers as well.
- It's really cool.
I mean, obviously it's amazing

that you've been able to
deliver better experiences

and products as a result
of the partnership,

but you know, if I think
of like the best use-case
for an AWS kind of customer,

it really is this volatile
ups and down customer.
So thank you so much for sharing.
Chris, to round up this interview,

what future technologies
are you excited about

that will help catapult
Australia's pathway

into this 100% renewable
future kind of goal
that we've got at the moment?

- I mean, I've mentioned
them a little bit before

already in the chat, but
the number one device
that is gonna change the whole game here
is electric vehicles.
An electric vehicle often has a--

Well, usually has battery
that is five to 10 times
the size of a typical home battery,

and fully charged, provides
for the average house

enough power to be able
to run for, you know,
three to four days independently.
And as we start to get that fleet

of electric cars across
Australia rolling up and up,

we're likely to get to
the point, you know,

probably in the next
sort of five to 10 years

where that fleet of electric
cars are by far and away

the biggest generation
asset in the country.

And so this opportunity of
being able to, you know,
power your home from your EV, and kind of
the classic image we have is, you know,
you drive to work during the day,

your business has solar
installed on the roof.
You plug your EV and at work there,

you're charged from that
cheap solar energy coming in

from your work and from
the grid during the day.
You come home, you arrive home,
you plug your car back in at sort of 6:00,

and all of a sudden you
you're powering your house

from your car now, and vehicle
to grid is kind of that term.

And that's increasingly
becoming available here
in Australia as well.

And so you're powering
your house from that car,

you're starting to power
your neighbor's house
from that car as well,

and starting to make sure
they're really driving that coal
out by this whole fleet of EVs.

You're discharging into the
grid at 6:00 each night.

And then as the winds
start to blow overnight,
maybe top your car up a little bit more.
As you wake up in the morning

your car kicks back in and
starts powering your house again.
And then the cycle just continues.

And really, I think what we're
likely to see in Australia
is this mix of solar plus EVs

being kind of the dominant
source of energy for the country,
which is gonna be this incredible sort of,
you know, diverse, distributed future

there that's gonna be
really amazing to see.
- I agree.
It's such an exciting space.
You're clearly so passionate about it.

I'm still learning, but I find
it so fascinating as well.
It is a complete game changer

and it's so important to
start building now, actually.
So we can start utilizing that technology
as soon as it does become more affordable
and available in Australia.
So thank you so much

for educating me, for
educating our audiences,

and we absolutely love
you guys as a customer.
So thanks for coming on the show.
- Thanks, Aley.
- Thanks, Chris.
